text: A&D-bf-u01 1.1 (a) (b) ... 1.3 (a) 0 ≥ 0 (b.c., n ← 0) n ∑ i=0 (2n + 1) ≥ (n + 1)2, ∀n ≥ 0 (i.h.) n+1 ∑ i=0 (2n + 1) ≥ (n + 2)2 (i.s., n ← n + 1) ( n ∑ i=0 (2n + 1)) + (2n + 3) ≥ n2 + 4n + 4 (subtract like terms) n ∑ i=0 (2n + 1) ≥ n2 + 2n + 1 (collect the square) n ∑ i=0 (2n + 1) i.h. ≥ (n + 1)2 □ a1 = 2, an≥1 = 6an − 2 (def. an) Since limm→∞ f(m) g(m) ≠ 0 but also limm→∞ g(m) f(m) ≠ 0, f and g grow asymptotically equal. □ (b) First, we cancel like terms 80⋅2m log(m)−2m 5⋅2m log(m)2 = 80 log(m)−1 5 log(m)2 . Since the limit as m approaches inﬁnity equals zero, f grows asymptotically slower than g. □ (c) We make use of the fact that log(m3) = 3 log m and apply l'Hôpital's rule. lim m→∞ 10m5 + 90m4 100m5 = (10m + 1) (100m) l’Hôpital = 10 100 = 10 m4 m4 lim m→∞ 80 log(m) − 1 5 log(m)2 l’Hôpital = 80 m 10 log(m) m = 8 log(m) ∞ → 0 lim m→∞ 3 log(m) log(m)3 l’Hôpital = 3 log(m)2 l’Hôpital = 1 2 log(m) m = m 2 log(m) l’Hôpital = 1 2 m = m 2 ∞ → ∞ Since limm→∞ f(m) g(m) = ∞, f grows asymptotically faster than g. □ (d)
